questions.title: What is empathy?
questions.description: Empathy is when we understand and care about another person's feelings. We try to imagine how they might feel, and connect with them over these shared feelings.

questions.title: The three ingredients of empathy
questions.description: The three ingredients of empathy are 1) feeling what the other person is feeling, 2) trying to understand why they feel this way, and 3) taking action to help them.

questions.title: The three ingredients in action
questions.description: It can be tricky to understand how these three ingredients combine to create empathy. Let's see them in action.

questions.question: Imagine you see your friend crying, which makes you feel sad. Are you feeling what your friend is feeling?

choices.answer: Yes, I am sharing their feelings.
No, I am not sharing their feelings.

questions.question: Now, imagine you remember a similar experience that made you feel sad. Are you are trying to understand their feelings?

choices.answer: Yes, I am using my own experiences to understand why they feel sad.
No, I am not using my own experiences to understand why they feel sad.

questions.question: Last, imagine giving your friend a hug, and telling them that you are here if they want to talk. Are you helping them?

choices.answer: Yes. After understanding their feelings, I am taking action to help them.
No. I am not taking action to help them.

questions.title: This is empathy!
questions.description: These three ingredients help us practice empathy. However, we might need to use other skills to help us too. Which skills do you think might be helpful?

questions.question: When we are practicing empathy with someone, which skill(s) might be helpful?

choices.answer: Listening carefully and responding with kindness
Asking them questions to better understand
Seeing the situation from their point-of-view
All of the above!

questions.title: All of the above!
questions.description: When we are practicing empathy with someone, it's important that we listen carefully and respond with kindness, ask questions to better understand, and try to see the situation from their point-of-view. Can you think of any other skills?

questions.title: Empathy doesn't mean feeling sorry for someone!
questions.description: Empathy is very different from sympathy, which is when we feel sorry for someone. When we practice empathy, we are connecting with someone over shared feelings and experiences.

questions.question: Your friend is too scared to go on a roller coaster with you. You say, "Oh, that's too bad!"

choices.answer: This is empathy (sharing their feelings)
This is sympathy (feeling sorry for them)

questions.title: This is sympathy.
questions.description: In this situation, you are only feeling sorry for them. You didn't try to share their feelings.

questions.question: How could you respond to your friend with empathy, or trying to share their feelings?

choices.answer: "I understand how you feel because I'm afraid of boat rides. It's hard."
"Just be brave!"
"I'm sorry that you can't go on the roller coaster."
"At least you can go on other rides."

questions.title: "I understand how you feel..."
questions.description: By responding this way, you are showing empathy. You are thinking about a similar situation that you have experienced, and connecting with your friend over these shared feelings.

questions.question: At lunch, a new student is alone. You remember feeling sad when you didn't know anyone, and ask them to sit with you.

choices.answer: This is empathy (sharing their feelings)
This is sympathy (feeling sorry for them)

questions.title: This is empathy!
questions.description: This is empathy because you remembered how you felt sad when you didn't know anyone, and this helped you understand how a new student might be feeling. Then, by asking them to sit with you, you even took action to help them!

questions.question: When is it the hardest for you to practice empathy?

choices.answer: When I'm tired
When I'm frustrated
When I don't know someone
When I don't know what to say

questions.title: Great job!
questions.description: Sometimes, it can be hard to practice empathy -- like when we are tired or frustrated, or we don't know the other person or what to say. What can we do in these situations?

questions.title: Take a moment to pause and reflect
questions.description: Why is it important to understand and share someone's feelings before taking action to help them?

questions.title: You are a superstar!
questions.description: Practicing empathy might not always be easy, but it's important that we still try whenever possible. Empathy helps us better understand others, and build strong relationships with them!
